title: Granite Falls, Washington
text:
Granite Falls is a city in <a href="Snohomish%20County%2C%20Washington">Snohomish County</a>, Washington, United States. It is located between the <a href="Pilchuck%20River">Pilchuck</a> and <a href="Stillaguamish%20River">Stillaguamish</a> rivers in the western foothills of the <a href="Cascade%20Range">Cascade Range</a>, northeast of <a href="Lake%20Stevens%2C%20Washington">Lake Stevens</a> and <a href="Marysville%2C%20Washington">Marysville</a>. The city is named for a <a href="waterfall">waterfall</a> north of downtown on the Stillagumish River, also accessible via the <a href="Mountain%20Loop%20Highway">Mountain Loop Highway</a>. It had a population of 3,364 at the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20census">2010 census</a>.
The site of Granite Falls was originally a <a href="portage">portage</a> for local <a href="Coast%20Salish">Coast Salish</a> tribes prior to the arrival of American settlers. The settlement was founded in 1883 and prospered after the discovery of gold and silver in the <a href="Monte%20Cristo%2C%20Washington">Monte Cristo</a> mines located east of Granite Falls on the <a href="Everett%20and%20Monte%20Cristo%20Railway">Everett and Monte Cristo Railway</a>. Granite Falls was <a href="plat">plat</a>ted in 1891 and incorporated as a fourth-class town on November 8, 1903.
History.
The <a href="Pilchuck%20River">Pilchuck River</a> and <a href="Stillaguamish%20River">Upper Stillaguamish</a> basin was historically inhabited by the <a href="Skykomish%20people">Skykomish people</a>, who used the modern-day site of Granite Falls as a <a href="portage">portage</a> along with other <a href="Coast%20Salish">Coast Salish</a> tribes. Several Skykomish <a href="archaeological%20site">archaeological site</a>s were discovered in the 1970s between modern-day Granite Falls and <a href="Lochsloy%2C%20Washington">Lochsloy</a>, with over 700 artifacts recovered from later excavation.
The first permanent European settler was Joseph Sous Enas from the <a href="Azores">Azores</a>, who staked a homestead claim in 1883 on land south of the present city. He was joined by other homesteaders who took advantage of open land that had been cleared by an earlier <a href="wildfire">wildfire</a>, nicknamed "the Big Burn". A <a href="school%20district">school district</a> was established in 1886, initially using an abandoned cabin as a <a href="One-room%20school">one-room schoolhouse</a> until a permanent school was built in 1893. The discovery of gold and silver in the Cascades, particularly around <a href="Monte%20Cristo%2C%20Washington">Monte Cristo</a>, lured miners and settlers to the Granite Falls area.
A general store and <a href="post%20office">post office</a> were established in 1890 at the corner of four homesteads, which would later form the center of the townsite <a href="plat">plat</a>ted in August 1891. The name "Granite Falls" was chosen for the settlement to replace the earlier name of "Portage". The <a href="Everett%20and%20Monte%20Cristo%20Railway">Everett and Monte Cristo Railway</a> reached Granite Falls on October 16, 1892, building a station for the town on the route between Monte Cristo and the county seat of <a href="Everett%2C%20Washington">Everett</a>.
On November 8, 1903, Granite Falls voted to become a city. It was officially incorporated as a fourth-class city on December 21, 1903. At the time, it had approximately 600 residents and several lumber mills. Electricity, sewers, sidewalks, telephones, cars, and all the amenities of modern life soon followed. A power plant was also constructed at the falls.
By World War I, the once bustling mining towns of Monte Cristo and Silverton were no longer shipping out ore. The railroad, now owned by <a href="Northern%20Pacific%20Railroad">Northern Pacific</a>, stopped running and the tracks were torn out in the early 1930s to make way for the Mountain Loop Highway.
Granite Falls between the world wars was a lumber town; logging companies felled trees, sawmills created lumber and shingle mills created shingles. The Great Depression, however, took its toll. By 1935, the population of Granite Falls was half what it was in 1925. Mills closed and people left to find work elsewhere. On April 26, 1933, a fire destroyed the Cascade Hotel in downtown Granite Falls and threatened other buildings. The historic hotel was rebuilt at the same site.
At the end of World War II, things looked bleak. The opening of Miller Shingle in 1946 (now the country's largest specialty lumber mill) meant jobs both in the woods and at the mill. Construction booms through <a href="Snohomish%20County%2C%20Washington">Snohomish</a> and <a href="King%20County%2C%20Washington">King</a> counties also meant jobs at the gravel pits dotted around Granite Falls. The city later became a <a href="bedroom%20community">bedroom community</a> for commuters working in <a href="Everett%2C%20Washington">Everett</a> and Lake Stevens for large companies.
Hard times would come again. In 1986, the United States Forest Service severely limited logging in <a href="old-growth%20forest">old-growth forest</a>s under its protection in an effort to save the <a href="northern%20spotted%20owl">northern spotted owl</a> from extinction. In June, 1990, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Department declared the spotted owl an endangered species, and in 1991, a federal court judge ruled the Forest Service's logging plan to save the owl was inadequate. Over one-fourth of old-growth forest on both public and private land were put off-limits to logging.
In the 21st century, Granite Falls has focused on attracting visitors to the natural environment and recreational opportunities along the Mt. Loop Highway. Expanded housing development has brought an increased population of families who commute to Everett, Seattle, and the Eastside to work. In 2001, the <a href="Tsubaki%20Grand%20Shrine%20of%20America">Tsubaki Grand Shrine of America</a> was given a 17-acre (7 ha) plot of land next to Kannagara Jinja (built by the Reverend of the shrine) in Granite Falls, which was built upon, combining the two places.
A truck <a href="bypass%20%28road%29">bypass</a> around the north side of downtown Granite Falls opened in 2010 to serve several <a href="quarry">quarries</a> to the northeast. A new high school campus was built near the bypass, along with a housing development with 327 homes in the late 2010s.
A downtown revitalization project began in the 2000s with renovations to buildings and a small city park. A new <a href="civic%20center">civic center</a> is planned along South Granite Avenue, including a <a href="city%20hall">city hall</a> that opened in 2019, a public plaza, a community center, and a <a href="Gym">gymnasium</a> for the <a href="Boys%20%26amp%3B%20Girls%20Clubs%20of%20America">Boys & Girls Club</a> that will also serve as an emergency shelter. The city government has also proposed promoting Granite Falls as a location for outdoor recreation retailers and businesses.
Geography.
Granite Falls is located in Snohomish County, approximately east of <a href="Everett%2C%20Washington">Everett</a>, the county seat, and northeast of <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a>. It lies on a plateau in the western foothills of the <a href="Cascade%20Range">Cascade Range</a> between the <a href="Stillaguamish%20River">South Fork Stillaguamish River</a> to the north and the <a href="Pilchuck%20River">Pilchuck River</a> to the south. Granite Falls is also the southern entrance to the <a href="Mountain%20Loop%20Highway">Mountain Loop Highway</a>, a scenic highway that continues into the Cascades to <a href="Darrington%2C%20Washington">Darrington</a>.
The <a href="city%20limits">city limits</a> are defined to the north by the Stillaguamish River, to the east by Iron Mountain, to the south by the Pilchuck River, and to the west by 174th Avenue Northeast. According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the city has a total area of , of which, is land and is water.
It is situated where the South Fork of the Stillaguamish River leaves its narrow mountain valley, which includes the namesake Granite Falls. The falls has a <a href="fishway">fishway</a> and a tunnel that were built in 1954, at the time the longest fish tunnel in the world. The area where the city was founded was called the "portage" by native tribes in the area, who used the flat area between the two rivers to portage their canoes when traveling. Iron Mountain, which sits at above sea level, lies east of downtown and is home to a <a href="quarry">quarry</a>. The <a href="Puget%20Sound%20faults">Rogers Belt</a>, a series of local faults, runs northwest from Granite Falls towards <a href="Mount%20Vernon%2C%20Washington">Mount Vernon</a>.
Climate.
The climate in this area has mild differences between highs and lows, and most of the rainfall occurs between October and May. Temperatures in the summer can be up to 10 degrees warmer than nearby Everett, due to its slightly inland location. According to the <a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20Climate%20Classification">Köppen Climate Classification</a> system, Granite Falls has a <a href="marine%20west%20coast%20climate">marine west coast climate</a>, abbreviated "Cfb" on climate maps.
Economy.
, Granite Falls has an estimated workforce population of 1,816 people, of which 1,746 are employed. The largest sectors of employment are educational and health services (21.6 percent), followed by construction (17.0%), manufacturing (16.6%), and retail (10.7%). The majority of workers in the city commute to other areas for employment, including 19 percent to Everett, 11 percent to Seattle, and 5 percent to <a href="Marysville%2C%20Washington">Marysville</a>. Approximately 5.2 percent of Granite Falls residents work within the city limits. Over 80 percent of workers commute in <a href="single-occupancy%20vehicle">single-occupant</a> vehicles, while 4 percent take <a href="public%20transportation">public transportation</a> or <a href="carpool">carpool</a>s.
The city had 202 registered businesses with 849 total jobs, according to 2012 estimates by the U.S. Census and <a href="Puget%20Sound%20Regional%20Council">Puget Sound Regional Council</a>. The largest providers of jobs in Granite Falls came from businesses in the education and services sectors. Several of the largest employers are located in an <a href="industrial%20park">industrial park</a> in the northeast corner of the city near the Mountain Loop Highway. They include electrical manufacturer B.I.C. and aerospace manufacturer Cobalt Industries. Granite Falls is located near several rock and gravel <a href="quarry">quarries</a>, which created traffic congestion in downtown that was later mitigated through the opening of a truck <a href="bypass%20%28road%29">bypass</a> in 2010.
Demographics.
The population was 3,364 at the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2010 census</a>. The current population as of 2017 population counts through the Office of Financial Management is 3,485. The city's population grew rapidly in the 1990s and 2000s due to new development and annexations.
The town has had an ongoing drug crisis due to the presence of <a href="meth">meth</a> and <a href="opioids">opioids</a>, which earned national coverage in the early 2000s.
2010 census.
As of the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20census">2010 census</a>, there were 3,364 people, 1,222 households, and 831 families residing in the city. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was . There were 1,344 housing units at an average density of . The <a href="Race%20and%20ethnicity%20in%20the%20United%20States%20Census">racial makeup</a> of the city was 87.6% White, 0.7% African American, 1.2% Native American, 1.5% Asian, 0.3% Pacific Islander, 3.2% from other races, and 5.5% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 7.5% of the population.
There were 1,222 households, of which 42.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 49.5% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 12.5% had a female householder with no husband present, 6.0% had a male householder with no wife present, and 32.0% were non-families. 25.6% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.75 and the average family size was 3.33.
The median age in the city was 34.4 years. 29.4% of residents were under the age of 18; 8.4% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 30.9% were from 25 to 44; 23.1% were from 45 to 64; and 8.4% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 50.2% male and 49.8% female.
2000 census.
As of the <a href="2000%20United%20States%20census">2000 census</a>, there were 2,347 people, 846 households, and 594 families residing in the city. The population density was 1,372.9 people per square mile (529.9/km2). There were 873 housing units at an average density of 510.7 per square mile (197.1/km2). The racial makeup of the city was 90.84% White, 0.68% African American, 2.09% Native American, 1.53% Asian, 0.09% Pacific Islander, 1.28% from other races, and 3.49% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 6.56% of the population.
There were 846 households, out of which 45.9% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 55.7% were married couples living together, 10.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 29.7% were non-families. 23.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 7.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.77 and the average family size was 3.31.
In the city, the age distribution of the population shows 33.2% under the age of 18, 7.5% from 18 to 24, 36.8% from 25 to 44, 15.6% from 45 to 64, and 6.9% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 30 years. For every 100 females, there were 98.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 98.1 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $47,643, and the median income for a family was $52,150. Males had a median income of $40,469 versus $26,809 for females. The <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> for the city was $17,425. About 5.1% of families and 7.2% of the population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 6.7% of those under age 18 and 11.3% of those age 65 or over.
Government and politics.
Granite Falls is a non-charter <a href="City%20government%20in%20Washington%20%28state%29">code city</a> with a <a href="Council%E2%80%93manager%20government">council–manager</a> system of government. The five members of the <a href="city%20council">city council</a> are elected <a href="at-large">at-large</a> to four-year terms in staggered odd years. The city council serves as the city's legislative body and selects a ceremonial <a href="mayor">mayor</a> from its members to manage meetings. The daily operations of the city government are overseen by the <a href="city%20manager">city manager</a>, who is appointed by the city council. Granite Falls switched from a "strong" <a href="mayor%E2%80%93council%20government">mayor–council government</a> in 2015 and hired former city administrator and public works director Brent Kirk as its first city manager.
The city government had nine full-time employees and an annual budget of $5.2 million in 2017. Municipal services include <a href="public%20safety">public safety</a>, <a href="public%20utilities">utilities</a>, street maintenance, and managing <a href="park">park</a>s and recreational activities. Granite Falls has contracted with the <a href="Snohomish%20County%20Sheriff%27s%20Office">Snohomish County Sheriff's Office</a> to provide policing services for the area since 2014, when the city's <a href="police%20department">police department</a> was disbanded. <a href="Firefighting">Firefighting</a> services are provided by Snohomish County Fire District 17, which covers of Granite Falls and surrounding unincorporated areas. The Granite Falls <a href="city%20hall">city hall</a> is located on South Granite Avenue in downtown at a building that opened in August 2019. It cost $3.9 million to construct, using loans and reserve funds, and replaced a smaller building across the street that had <a href="accessibility">accessibility</a> issues.
At the federal level, Granite Falls is part of the <a href="Washington%27s%201st%20congressional%20district">1st congressional district</a>, which includes the northeastern areas of the <a href="Puget%20Sound%20region">Puget Sound region</a> and is represented by Democrat <a href="Suzan%20DelBene">Suzan DelBene</a>. At the state level, Granite Falls shares the <a href="Washington%27s%2039th%20legislative%20district">39th legislative district</a> with Arlington, the <a href="Skykomish%20Valley">Skykomish Valley</a>, and eastern <a href="Skagit%20County%2C%20Washington">Skagit County</a>. The city lies in the <a href="Snohomish%20County%20Council">Snohomish County Council</a>'s 1st district, which includes most of the county north of Everett and Lake Stevens.
Culture.
Granite Falls has several annual community events, the largest of which is Railroad Days in early October. The Railroad Days festival was established in 1965 by a schoolteacher and celebrates the city's local history. It attracts about 5,000 visitors and includes a <a href="parade">parade</a>, a <a href="street%20fair">street fair</a>, <a href="carnival">carnival</a> rides, and tours.
The city's <a href="historical%20society">historical society</a> opened its museum in October 2007 at a two-story building with of space. The museum launched a digitization project in 2016, using volunteer labor to preserve photographs and newspaper records.
Arts.
The Granite Falls area has been home to several renowned artists, including <a href="Kenneth%20Callahan">Kenneth Callahan</a> and <a href="Guy%20Anderson">Guy Anderson</a> in the 1940s and 1950s. The city has several works of <a href="public%20art">public art</a>, including downtown murals and sculptures at local schools. Among them is a wood carving of <a href="Bigfoot">Bigfoot</a> created by a local <a href="cryptozoologist">cryptozoologist</a>. In 2000, Granite Falls erected several sculptures depicting <a href="toilet">toilet</a>s to raise funds for a <a href="public%20restroom">public restroom</a> as part of the annual Art in the Parks festival.
The 1977 movie "<a href="Joyride%20%281977%20film%29">Joyride</a>", set in <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a>, and the 2018 movie "<a href="Outside%20In%20%28film%29">Outside In</a>" were partially filmed in Granite Falls. A local music venue at the Scherrer Ranch was closed in 1995 by the county government after it constructed a stage without permits.
Parks and recreation.
Granite Falls is located near recreational areas along the Mountain Loop Highway in the <a href="Mount%20Baker%E2%80%93Snoqualmie%20National%20Forest">Mount Baker–Snoqualmie National Forest</a>, including sites for hiking, camping, and fishing. Among the major attractions on the Mountain Loop Highway are the <a href="ghost%20town">ghost town</a> of <a href="Monte%20Cristo%2C%20Washington">Monte Cristo</a> and the <a href="Big%20Four%20Ice%20Caves">Big Four Ice Caves</a>. Other major recreational areas near Granite Falls include <a href="Lake%20Bosworth%2C%20Washington">Lake Bosworth</a> and <a href="Lake%20Roesiger%2C%20Washington">Lake Roesiger</a> to the south, which are both <a href="fish%20stocking">stocked</a> by the county government.
The city government owns eight parks and <a href="nature%20preserve">nature preserve</a>s, ranging from small neighborhood parks to city recreational areas. The largest is Frank Mason Park, which encompasses the Lake Gardner and of surrounding land that has been partially developed. The park has a <a href="fishing%20pier">fishing pier</a>, restrooms, picnic tables, and walking paths. The city and local <a href="school%20district">school district</a> maintain several athletic facilities for residents, as well as a <a href="skate%20park">skate park</a> and <a href="dog%20park">dog park</a>.
Media.
The first newspaper in Granite Falls, the "Post", began publishing on July 23, 1903. It was later replaced by the "Record" in 1922 and the "Press", which later merged with a newspaper in Lake Stevens. Granite Falls is also served by two regional daily newspapers: "<a href="The%20Everett%20Herald">The Everett Herald</a>" and "<a href="The%20Seattle%20Times">The Seattle Times</a>".
Granite Falls has a <a href="public%20library">public library</a> that is operated by the regional <a href="Sno-Isle%20Libraries">Sno-Isle Libraries</a> system, which annexed the city in 1995. The library building is located east of downtown Granite Falls and was initially owned by the city government until it was transferred to Sno-Isle in 2012.
Religion.
The <a href="Tsubaki%20Grand%20Shrine%20of%20America">Tsubaki Grand Shrine of America</a> is located west of Granite Falls on overlooking the Pilchuck River. The <a href="Shinto%20shrine">Shinto shrine</a> is one of a few in the United States and was dedicated in 2001 after moving from <a href="Stockton%2C%20California">Stockton, California</a>. The Tsubaki Grand Shrine is open to the public and hosts several annual festivals and religious ceremonies.
The Holy Cross Catholic Church in downtown Granite Falls was built in 1903 and served as a satellite <a href="Parish%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">parish</a> of St. Michael's Catholic Church until 2004. The church's congregation was split between Granite Falls and Lake Stevens until a new church was constructed in 2008. The old building was renovated for a bilingual Christian church that opened in 2015. The <a href="The%20Church%20of%20Jesus%20Christ%20of%20Latter-day%20Saints">LDS Church</a> established a local <a href="Ward%20%28LDS%20Church%29">ward</a> in the 1990s and opened a dedicated chapel adjacent to Granite Falls High School in 2009.
Education.
The city has four public schools that are operated by the <a href="Granite%20Falls%20School%20District">Granite Falls School District</a>, which also serves unincorporated communities to the northwest and near the Mountain Loop Highway. The school district had an enrollment of over 2,100 students in 2018 and employed 107 teachers and 80 other staff members. Granite Falls has two <a href="elementary%20school">elementary school</a>s (Mountain Way and Monte Cristo), Granite Falls Middle School, Granite Falls High School, and Crossroads High School, an <a href="alternative%20school">alternative school</a> program. Andrea Peterson of Monte Cristo Elementary School was named the 2007 <a href="National%20Teacher%20of%20the%20Year">National Teacher of the Year</a>.
The first <a href="One-room%20school">schoolhouse</a> in Granite Falls opened in 1893 and was replaced by a new building at the site in 1910. A larger building opened in 1938 for <a href="Granite%20Falls%20High%20School%20%28Washington%29">Granite Falls High School</a>, which later moved to a nearby building in 1964 and opened at its new campus in January 2008. The high school's athletic teams, nicknamed the Tigers, compete in the North Sound Conference; a 1,700-seat <a href="American%20football">football</a> stadium opened at the new high school campus in 2018, replacing the Hi-Jewel Stadium at the former high school, which had been converted into a middle school.
Infrastructure.
Transportation.
Granite Falls is the terminus of <a href="Washington%20State%20Route%2092">State Route 92</a>, which connects the area to <a href="Washington%20State%20Route%209">State Route 9</a> in Lake Stevens. A <a href="bypass%20%28road%29">bypass</a> for freight traffic was completed around the north side of the city in 2010 at a cost of $28.8 million. The scenic <a href="Mountain%20Loop%20Highway">Mountain Loop Highway</a> begins in Granite Falls and travels east into the Cascade Mountains before turning north to reach <a href="Darrington%2C%20Washington">Darrington</a>. It is used by an estimated 55,000 tourists annually and provides access to recreational areas in the <a href="Mount%20Baker%E2%80%93Snoqualmie%20National%20Forest">Mount Baker–Snoqualmie National Forest</a>.
<a href="Community%20Transit">Community Transit</a>, the countywide <a href="public%20transportation">public transportation</a> agency, has one bus route serving Granite Falls. It connects the city to Lake Stevens and <a href="Everett%20Station">Everett Station</a>, with extended service to the <a href="Boeing%20Everett%20Factory">Boeing Everett Factory</a> during peak hours. The nearest airport to Granite Falls is <a href="Paine%20Field">Paine Field</a> in Everett.
Utilities.
<a href="Electric%20power">Electric power</a> in Granite Falls is supplied by the <a href="Snohomish%20County%20Public%20Utility%20District">Snohomish County Public Utility District</a> (PUD), a consumer-owned <a href="public%20utility">public utility</a> that serves all of Snohomish County. The city government purchases its <a href="purified%20water">tap water</a> from the PUD, which is sourced from the City of Everett system at <a href="Spada%20Lake">Spada Lake</a> and Lake Chaplain. Since 2012, the PUD has also supplied water to Granite Falls that is sourced from <a href="groundwater">groundwater</a> wells near Lake Stevens and treated to be similar to the water from the City of Everett system. The city government also manages a sanitary <a href="sewage">sewage</a> system that terminates at a <a href="sewage%20treatment%20plant">treatment plant</a> that discharges water into the Pilchuck River.
<a href="Natural%20gas">Natural gas</a> service for the city is provided by <a href="Puget%20Sound%20Energy">Puget Sound Energy</a>, a regional gas utility company. The city government contracts with <a href="Waste%20Management">Waste Management</a> to provide curbside collection and disposal of <a href="municipal%20solid%20waste">garbage</a>, <a href="single-stream%20recycling">recycling</a>, and <a href="yard%20waste">yard waste</a>. The Granite Falls area also has two recycling and disposal centers operated by Snohomish County. Telecommunications services are provided by <a href="Verizon">Verizon</a> and <a href="Comcast">Comcast</a>.
Healthcare.
The nearest <a href="general%20hospital">general hospital</a>s to Granite Falls are <a href="Providence%20Regional%20Medical%20Center%20Everett">Providence Medical Center</a> in Everett and <a href="Cascade%20Valley%20Hospital">Cascade Valley Hospital</a> in Arlington. The city's medical <a href="clinic">clinic</a> was part of the Cascade Valley system, which was absorbed into <a href="Skagit%20Regional%20Health">Skagit Regional Health</a> in 2016.
